body.head: PCT 22: An embassy to the Snakes

p.seg: mitoni ninikotwâsinân , ê-sipwêhtêyâhk . There were six of us who set out.

wiyâpahtamâhkoh mîkiwâhpah , nikâsôwanân , êkâ ta-wâpamikoyâhkok ayahciyiniwak , When we saw any tipis, we hid from the people, lest the Blackfoot see us. CHECK ?? kâsow VTA - RELATIONAL -wânân 1eAIrel3
êh-pimohtatâyâhk ôtêh ohci ayôwinisah , êh-ntawih-wîtaskiyâhk wâhyaw awasâpisk . We were carrying garments with us, from here, for we were bound on an embassy far beyond the Rocky Mountains.

piyisk nôtihtênân asinîwaciy , têpiskâki pikoh êh-pimohtêyâhk , êkâ awiyak ta-nôtinikoyâhk , ê-wîh-kakwê-takohtêyâhk itêh k-êtohtêyâhk . At last we came to the Rocky Mountains, walking the while only at night, lest anyone fight with us, for we meant to reach our destination.
piyisk awasâpisk nitakohtânân . At last we arrived beyond the Rockies.
êkotê piyisk mînisah miywâsinwah , iyikonk êh-takohtêyâhk . The berries were ripe by the time we arrived.

iyikohk êh-wâpahtamâhk mîkiwâhpah , namoya nikîh-pîhtokânân , osâm êkâ ê-kîh-nipâcik oskinîkiwak , êkâ ta-wâpamikoyâhkok . When we came in sight of the tipis, we did not enter, for we did not care to have them see us before the young warriors were asleep.
piyisk kinwês âkawâyihk nkâsônân . For quite a while we stayed in hiding.
êkosi kîtahtawê êkwah nkaskihtânân pîhtiyisk êh-cimatêk mîkiwâhp , êh-okimâwit kinêpikoyiniw . Then in time we managed to gain the tipi which stood in the center, that of the Snake who was chief.
nipîhtokânân , êh-tipiskâk . We entered when it was dark.
êh-pîhtokêyâhk , wanskâw awa okimâw . When we entered, the chief arose from his couch.
êkosi apisîs piko pônasiwak . So they made only a small fire.
wîwa nayêstaw nistiwak , êh-nîsôskwêwêt . With his wives, they were only three, for he had two wives.
êkosi pêyak wayawîw awa , êh-atotak , niwîcêwâkan ; So then I bade one of my companions go out;
kahkiyaw pîhtokatâw ayôwinisah ôhi êh-pimohtatâyâhk , êh-nitawih-mêkiyâhk , mîna nanâtohk akohpah . he brought in all the things we carried with us to give away, and all kinds of blanket-robes.
êkos îsi pakitinamawâw awa kâ-pîhtokawâyâhk . Then they were set down before him whose tent we had entered.
êkosi wîwah kitotêw ; wayawiyiwah . Then he spoke to his wives; they went out.
kîtahtawê pîhtokêyiwah wîwah . Presently his wives came in.
wîhkâc pê-pîhtokêyiwa ôhtâwiya . At times his father came in.
êkosi ka-kitotêw ôhtâwiya ; ati-wayawiyiwa . So then he spoke to his father; the latter would go out.
êkosi êh-pîhtokêyit ôhtâwiya , wah-wayawîwak ôki iskwêwak , kotakihk êh-tohtêcik . In this fashion, when his father came in, his wives would go out, and go to some other place.
êkosi kotakak okimâwak pâh-pîhtokêwak . Then other chiefs began to come in.
êkosi mitonih sâkaskinêwak . The tent became crowded.

êkosi êkwah awa okimâw pîkiskwêw :
hâw , êh-âtah-sâkwêyimoyân , kikîh-miyinâwâw t-ôkimâwiyân . Then that chieftain spoke: “Now then, although I was unwilling, you made me chief.

seg.q: êkosi kintawêyimitinâwâw êkâ ta-pâsitahkoskêyêk ôma kâ-wîh-ititakok .
seg.gloss: Accordingly, I now ask of you not to overstep that which I shall tell you.

seg.q: kîspin kîh-pêh-macih-nôcihtâcik , kitêmiwâwak tahtoh kâ-miyosicik kah-kimotamâkawinâwâw ; êkosi mîna niyah nkah-nipahikok .
seg.gloss: Had they come here with evil designs, you would have been robbed of as many of your horses as are handsome; and likewise, me they would have killed.
Without my knowledge, and while I was yet asleep, they made a fire.
Then they awakened me.

seg.q: êk ohci ôhi k-âstêkih êh-pêh-ntawih-miyicik ayôwinisah , mîna môsw-asiniyah , mîna kaskitêw .
seg.gloss: Their purpose was to come give me these things that lie here, garments, and bullets, and powder.
Accordingly, I ask of you that you be good friends.
Tomorrow I shall call upon you to come here and make friends with them.

p.seg: hâw , êkosi êsi-wîhtamâtakok , itêw otôskinîkiyima ; There, this is what I had to say to you,” he said to his followers;

seg.gloss: “It was for this that I summoned you.”

p.seg: hâw , omah k-êtwêyin namoya nka-kî-miyâskênân kipîkiskwêwin , itik ôhi otôskinîkiyima . “Now, this which you have spoken we shall not by any chance transgress, this speech of yours,” his followers answered him.

seg.gloss: “But now, what sort of men are they?”

p.seg: êkosi kakwêcimêw awa okimâw . Thereupon the chief asked them.

wîhtamawêw pêyak awa nâpêw , êwako ciwayân k-êtiht :
nêhiyawak niyanân , itêw ; One of those men, the one whose name was Tehiwayan, told him: “We are Cree,” he told him;

seg.gloss: “And we have come with the express purpose of visiting you.

p.seg: wâhyaw askîhk kiyâm nka-wâpahtênân , êh-itêyihtamâhk , êwakô ohci ôtah kâ-wâpamiyâhk , itêw . 'We shall see much of the earth,' was our thought, and therefore you see us here,” he told him.
êkosi ntawih-kawisimôwak ôki okimâwak . Then those chieftains went home to bed.
êkwêyâk êko kitotêw awa ôhtâwiya . Only then did he address his father.
êkosi ati-wayawiyiwa . Thereupon the latter went out.
ê-kîh-kîwêyit ôhtâwiya awa okimâw , êkwêyêk êkwah pîhtwâwak . When the chief's father had gone home, only then did they smoke.
êkosi pîhtokêyiwa wîwah awah okimâw , êh-pêtâyit ta-mîcisocik ôki kâ-ntawih-wîtaskîcik . Then the chief's wives came in, bringing food for those to eat who had come to make a treaty.
wîcêwêwak ôhih okimâwa . the chief went with them.
sipwêhtêwak ; nâtêwak otêmiwâwa mînah kotakah ayôwinisah . They went from there; they fetched their horses and their other things.
êkos êh-takohtêcik , sâ-sakahpitêwak otêmiwâwa . Then, when they came back, they tethered their horses.
êkos îsi pâh-pîhtokatâwak ôki iskwêwak ôhi nêhiyawa kêkway êh-pêh-miyikocik . Then those women began to bring into their dwelling the things which the Cree had given them when they came.
êkos îsi pîhtokêwak kahkiyaw ôki nâpêwak . Then all those men went into the tent.
êkosi êkwah kawisimôwak . So then they went to bed.
êh-wâpahk , waniskâwak . When day broke, they got up.
kwayask pamihâwak . They were well cared for.
ê-kîh-mîcisocik , nahascikêwak ôki iskwêwak . When they had eaten, the women put the dwelling in order.
ôhtâwiyah aw ôkimaw pîhtokêyiwa . the chief's father entered.
wîhtamawêw êh-tah-têpwâtimiht kotakah okimâwah . He told him of the arrival of other chiefs who had been summoned by calling.
kahkiyaw mitonih sâkaskinêwak ôma mîkiwâhp . When all were there, they entirely filled that tent.
kîtahtawê kotak okimâw ntawi-ntomâw . Presently one more chief was sent for.
takosin êwakô . He arrived.
êkosi êkwah wîh-nipahêw êwakô ncawâc awa okimâw . Then this chief thought it best to kill them.

seg.gloss: “Now then, my brother in arms, you will kill me too.
If you are to kill them, you will kill me too.”

p.seg: êkosi ntomâw kotak iskwêw êh-nêhiyawêt . Then a woman was called who spoke Cree.
pêy-itohtêw êkotah ; pîhtokêw . She came there; she came into the tent.
êkosi kakwêcimâw awah nâpêw nêhiyaw . Then that one Cree was questioned.

seg.q: âh , namôya ! namôya êh-pêh-nipahtâkêyân , mînah namoya êh-nôhtê-kimotoyân .
seg.gloss: “Oh, no! It was not for murder that I came here, and not because I wanted to steal.

p.seg: mahtih nka-nitawih-pîhtwân ; mîna nka-nitawih-mîcison , êh-itêyihtamân , itwêw awa nêhiyaw . 'Suppose I go and smoke; suppose I go and eat,' was what I had in mind,” said that Cree.
êkosi êh-wîhtamâht awah okimâw . Then that chief was told this.

êkosi êkwah ôkwêmêsah misatimwah nîso miyêw êh-mihkawikiyit , kiyâm êkâh ta-pisiskêyimâyit ôhi kâ-nôhtên-nipahâyit . Thereupon he gave his friend two swift horses, that he might cease to mind those whom he desired to kill.
tâpwêh naskomik . He consented.
êkos îsi miyêw cistêmâwa , môsasiniyah , kaskitêw , mîna ayôwinisah . Then likewise he gave him tobacco, bullets, powder, and garments.
êkosi êkwah kîwêwak . Thereupon they went home.
kapê-pipon êkotê ayâwak ôki nêhiyawak . Those Cree stayed there all winter.
mitoni misatimwa mihcêt miyâwak . They were given very many horses.
êkosi êh-nîpihk , wawêyîwak . Then, when summer came, they made ready to depart.
êkwah pê-wîcêwêw okwêmêsah kinêpikoyiniwa . The Snake who was the Cree leader's friend accompanied him a ways.
iyikohk wâhyaw êh-pêy-âyâcik , êkoyikohk kîwêyiwa okwêmêsah . When they had gone quite a ways on the hither journey, only then did his friend go back.
nyânanomitanaw âyiwâk nkotwâsik miyikok misatimwah . The others had given them fifty-six horses.

êkosi êkwah ,
wâpamacih ayahciyiniw , wîh-nipahiskih , wêpinâhkanik ôki misatimwak kâ-mîkawiyêk . And so then, “If you see Blackfoot and they want to kill you, give rein to these horses that have been given to you.

seg.gloss: They are very swift.
Simply flee for home.
In this way you will easily reach your country.”

p.seg: êkos îsi kîwêwak . So then they went home.
êkosi têpiskâki iyikohk , pimohtêw , êkâ ta-wâpamikot ayahciyiniwa . Then only at night did he march, so as not to be seen by the Blackfoot.
piyisk miyâskawêw . At last he had passed them.
iyikohk kêkâc êh-piponiyik , êkoyikohk takosin . When it was almost winter, he arrived.
pêyak ayahciyiniwah êh-kimotamâkocik , atimêwak . One Blackfoot had stolen horses from them, and him they overtook.
êkosi êkonih maskamêwak . They took them away from him.
êkosi ê-wîh-nipahikocik , nipahêwak . Then, when he tried to kill them, they killed him.
êkos îsi kîwêwak . So they went home.
êkotah ohci kâ-kîh-ihtakohk kiyôtêwin wîtaskîwin , êkâ ta-kimotamâtocik têmiwâwa . So began the mutual visiting and the alliance and the agreement not to steal each other's horses.
êkoyikohk pêyak pipon , iyikohk êsa ê-kih-sipwêhtêt , pîtos-iyiniwa otaskiyihk ê-kîh-ayât . It was one year from the time when he had set out on his visit to the foreigners' country.
tâpwê nisâkihikok kinêpikoyiniwak , kîh-itwêw êwako kisêyiniw : “Truly, the Snake people were fond of me,” said that old man;

seg.q: ptanêh êkâ wîhkâc macih-wîcêhtocik , wiyâpahtotwâwi , nikîh-itwân mâna , ispih êh-okimâwiyân .
seg.gloss: “'Would they might never deal wrongly with each other, when they see one another,' I used to say, when I was chief.

seg.q: êyakô ohci nanâtohk ayîsiyiniwak k-ô-kîh-sâkihicik : namoya wîhkâc n-ôh-nipahtâkân .
seg.gloss: That is why all kinds of people loved me: I never killed people.
All the time I was in the Blackfoots' country.

seg.q: êkosi kiyîwêyâni ntaskîhk isi , nkîh-mâna-pîkiskâtâwak ayahciyiniwak .
seg.gloss: And when I went home, they would always regret my departure, the Blackfoot.
Because I was of decent and righteous character, is why I reached old age.
'That is the way you must try to be, my children, even thus.

seg.q: kahkiyaw ayîsiyiniw ka-miyoh-wîcêwâwâw , nkîh-itâwak mâna ntawâsimisak .
seg.gloss: You must deal rightly with every human being,' I always told my children.”

p.seg: hâw , êkoyikohk . There, that is all.
hâw , êkosi . There, even so.
